newsitem.title: UK: EU seen awarding up to 50,000 T sugar at tender.
newsitem.headline: EU seen awarding up to 50,000 T sugar at tender.

text.p: The European Union (EU) is expected to award as much as 50,000 tonnes of current series white sugar at its weekly tender later on Wednesday, traders said.
A range of 30,000 to 50,000 tonnes was suggested for this week's award, compared with 24,000 tonnes last week.
But with the current series approaching its close it was difficult to gauge the level of trade interest remaining to apply for licences, they said.
"Nobody really knows -- I would imagine if anyone has got any business to do they'll come out and do it this week," said one trader, citing a favourable dollar rate.
"But we are getting towards the end of it...it might be very little."

The maximum restitution level was forecast at 39.475 Ecus per 100 kilos, based on a notional MATIF August/October differential of 0.631 Ecus, which is applied as a discount to a straight October calculation.
Last week the EU awarded a maximum 40.850 Ecus.

Traders said the 1996/97 export series was still lagging in its cumulative tonnage awards and was expected to turn out a shortfall of up to 150,000 tonnes on the balance sheet figure of 2.84 million tonnes.
The last tender for the current season will be held on July 30 and the first tender of the new season on August 6.
